content.description:
Thoughtful moves, with the crux handholds very abrasive. 

  Up the crack, and straight to the top. 

  The lower part is also done as a boulder problem, called "Army Intelligence". 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is standard rack. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Army Rampart sector.
content.location:
Crack about 12 feet right of the big low roof and left of fairly blank face. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Multi-stage adventure with four or five phases of different rock styles requiring different techniques. 

  Up the corner to get hands on horizontal crack. Traverse left to get hands on a rather wobbly rather large rock.    . . (Variation: Instead continue straight up to the top of the right-facing corner (5.11a).   Next over the bulge and right on slab up to small tree. Finish up steep face to top of cliff. 

note: Be sure to check the security of this large wobbly rock before trying this route. And of course the belayer or any other member of the party should not stand anywhere near under that rock. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Army Rampart sector.
content.location:
Right-facing corner with thin crack starting five feet up, at right side of big low roof. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Fun moves, but rather short for a roped climb. 

  Up to under roof, traverse right to its end, then escape up over a rather wobbly rather large rock. Stop when get feet onto the top of that rock, then lower off. Or perhaps continue up right by joining the upper section of the route "Smoke em If You Got em" (but this is more difficult, and not well-protected on Top-Rope). 

note: Be sure to check the security of this large wobbly rock before trying this route. And of course the belayer or any other member of the party should not stand anywhere near under that rock. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Army Rampart sector.
content.location:
Under big roof about ten feet up, just left of dead tree which is at left side of a big roof five feet up. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Interesting moves, but pretty short for a roped climb. 

  Work up through flakes and underclings up to positive horizontal hold about 15-18 feet up, then lower off. Or perhaps join one of the routes on either side to continue higher. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Army Rampart sector.
content.location:
Group of roughly-vertical flakes about five feet right from right side of big low roof with big right-facing corner above. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
The difficult section is some off-width moves in the wide crack high near the top. So if you actually like off-width technique, or feel like you need to practice it even if you don't like it, this climb is for you. 

  Work around left side to get up on top of rock over left end of the big low roof. Then up the wide crack to the top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is not accurately known. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Army Rampart sector.
content.location:
At the left end of a big roof about ten feet up with a big tree in front of its left side. The big roof is toi the left of a dead tree which is at left side of a big roof five feet up. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Top-Roping + Bouldering area on right (SE) side of the Yankee Ramparts East area. 

  Top-Rope: One way to get access to set up an anchor using trees or rocks above top of this cliff is to hike up dirt ramp around the left end, then scramble up (3rd class with at least on exposed move). Or see other ideas on the Alexander Hamilton sector page. 

  Bouldering problems are linked from this area page under The Loop under the Powerlinez Bouldering section. 

  Roped-climbing routes in this area include (L to R) . . . 

 A Taste of Yosemite

Ramapo River Apparition

Smoke em If You Got em (Wiggly Rock version) Army Strong Wilie Mae
